nodes.text: Mrs. Davis from Unit 2A calls you, clearly frustrated. 'I've had enough! The tenant in 3B has been playing loud music until 2 AM every night this week. I have to get up early for work, and I can't take it anymore!' You can hear the exhaustion in her voice.

choices.text: Apologize sincerely and promise to investigate immediately
Ask for more specific details about the noise
Suggest she try talking to the neighbor first

nodes.text: You head to Unit 3B right away. You can hear faint music coming from inside. When you knock, a young tenant opens the door, looking surprised to see you.

choices.text: Politely explain the noise complaint and ask for cooperation
Firmly remind them about quiet hours policy

nodes.text: Mrs. Davis provides specific times and describes the type of music. 'It's that electronic dance music, and it's so loud I can feel the bass through the walls. Last night it went until 2:30 AM!' This detailed information will help you address the issue more effectively.

choices.text: Thank her for the details and go speak with Unit 3B
Ask if she has documented the incidents

nodes.text: Armed with specific information, you approach Unit 3B. The tenant is more receptive when you mention the exact times and impact: 'Oh wow, I had no idea it was that loud or that late. I'll definitely be more careful about the volume and time.'

choices.text: Suggest they use headphones after 10 PM

nodes.text: The tenant in 3B is apologetic: 'I had no idea I was being so loud! I work late shifts and thought everyone was asleep. I'll definitely keep it down after 10 PM.' They seem genuinely sorry and cooperative.

choices.text: Thank them and follow up with Mrs. Davis

nodes.text: You call Mrs. Davis back to let her know the situation has been resolved. She sounds relieved: 'Thank you so much for handling this quickly. I really appreciate a property manager who listens and takes action.' The noise issue appears to be resolved amicably.

Both tenants are happy with the headphone solution. Mrs. Davis calls later: 'What a great idea! I can't hear anything now, and I know they can still enjoy their music. Perfect compromise!' This creative solution strengthened relationships with both tenants.
The tenant becomes defensive: 'I didn't know there were specific quiet hours. Fine, I'll keep it down, but this building has thin walls anyway.' They comply but seem annoyed by your approach.

choices.text: Follow up with Mrs. Davis about the resolution

nodes.text: Mrs. Davis is satisfied that you addressed the issue, though she mentions: 'I hope they actually follow through. Thank you for taking care of it.' The immediate problem is solved, but the tenant relationship could be better.

Mrs. Davis sounds frustrated: 'I shouldn't have to deal with this myself! That's what I pay management fees for!' She hangs up, clearly unhappy with your response. You'll need to handle this situation more proactively.

choices.text: Call her back and offer to handle it personally

nodes.text: You call Mrs. Davis back: 'I apologize for my initial response. You're absolutely right - this is my responsibility. I'll go speak with Unit 3B right now.' She appreciates the follow-up, though some damage to the relationship has been done.

choices.text: Go to Unit 3B and resolve the issue

nodes.text: Mr. Johnson from Unit 7C calls. 'Hi, there's a bit of a leaky faucet in my kitchen. It's not major, but it's been dripping for a day or two. Can someone take a look when you have a moment?'

choices.text: Tell him you'll send someone over today.
Ask him if he can wait until tomorrow's scheduled maintenance rounds.
Suggest he try tightening it himself first.

nodes.text: You head to Unit 7C. Mr. Johnson greets you. The faucet is indeed dripping steadily. 'Thanks for coming so quickly,' he says.

choices.text: Attempt to fix it yourself (QTE).
Promise to send a professional plumber later.

nodes.text: Mr. Johnson sounds a bit disappointed but agrees to wait. 'Alright, I guess. Hopefully, it doesn't get worse.'
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: Mr. Johnson will wait. You've saved immediate effort but slightly lowered his satisfaction.

nodes.text: Mr. Johnson sounds hesitant. 'Uh, I'm not really good with tools. I'd rather not make it worse.' He doesn't sound pleased.

choices.text: Insist he tries or waits for a fee.
Apologize and say you'll inspect it now.

nodes.text: Mr. Johnson is clearly unhappy. 'Fine. I'll just let it drip then.' This will likely lead to a worse report later.
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: Mr. Johnson is upset. The leak continues.

nodes.text: You decide to try fixing the leaky faucet yourself. It looks like a worn-out washer. This might save some money if you can do it.

qte.instructionText: Try to tighten the valve just right. Click 'Stop Bar' when the moving bar is in the green zone!

nodes.text: Success! You tightened it perfectly, and the leak has stopped. Mr. Johnson is impressed. 'Great job! Thanks a lot!'
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: You successfully fixed the sink and saved some money. Mr. Johnson is happy.

nodes.text: Oops! You either over-tightened it or didn't get it right. The leak persists. Mr. Johnson looks a bit concerned.

choices.text: Apologize and call a professional plumber.
Say you'll come back with better tools later.

nodes.text: You call a professional plumber. They fix the sink later that day. It costs a bit, but the problem is solved.
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: The plumber fixed the sink. Mr. Johnson is satisfied, though it cost some money.

nodes.text: Mr. Johnson doesn't look thrilled. 'Oh, okay. So it's still dripping then?'
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: You failed to fix the sink and have delayed a proper repair. Mr. Johnson is not happy.

nodes.text: You are in your office. The phone rings. It's Mrs. Davis from Unit 10B. 'The new tenants in 10A are playing loud music again! It's shaking my walls! You have to do something!' Her voice is sharp with annoyance.

choices.text: Promise to talk to Unit 10A immediately.
Tell her you'll look into it when you have time.
Advise her to talk to them herself first.

nodes.text: You go to Unit 10A and speak with the tenants (they identify as 'NPC_TENANT_10A'). They are apologetic and agree to turn down the music. Mrs. Davis calls back later, sounding much calmer, to thank you.
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: The noise issue is resolved for now. Mrs. Davis is pleased with your prompt action.

nodes.text: Hours later, Mrs. Davis calls back, absolutely furious. 'The music never stopped! I'm going to report you to the owner for negligence! This is unacceptable!' The call ends abruptly.

choices.text: Quickly go to Unit 10A now and address the music.
Decide to issue a formal lease violation warning to 10A without visiting.

nodes.text: Mrs. Davis calls back a short while later. 'I tried talking to them, and they were rude to me! Now the music is even louder! You need to handle this!' She sounds more upset than before.

choices.text: Apologize and head to Unit 10A immediately.
Explain you'll send a written notice to Unit 10A.

nodes.text: You rush to Unit 10A. They are surprised to see you, claiming they weren't playing music loudly for long. They turn it off. It's hard to know who to believe, but the noise is stopped.
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: The immediate noise issue is resolved, but the situation remains tense and unclear.

nodes.text: You draft and send a formal lease violation notice to Unit 10A. You inform Mrs. Davis. She seems partially mollified but skeptical it will work long-term.
nodes.endText: Scenario Ended: A formal notice has been issued. The long-term effectiveness is uncertain.

nodes.text: At 11 PM, you receive an urgent call from a tenant: 'There's water everywhere! A pipe burst in my bathroom and it's flooding into the hallway!' You need to act fast to minimize damage.

choices.text: Rush to the scene immediately
Call the emergency plumber first, then head over

nodes.text: You arrive to find water pouring from a burst pipe behind the toilet. The tenant has placed buckets, but water is still spreading. You need to shut off the water supply quickly.

choices.text: Attempt to shut off the water valve yourself
Call for professional help immediately

nodes.text: You locate the water shutoff valve, but it's old and stiff. You need to turn it with just the right amount of force - too little and it won't budge, too much and you might break it!

qte.instructionText: Stop the bar in the green zone to apply the right amount of force!

nodes.text: Perfect! You successfully shut off the water supply. The flooding stops immediately. The tenant looks relieved: 'Wow, you really know what you're doing! Thank you for acting so quickly.' Your quick thinking prevented major damage.
The valve handle snaps under too much pressure! Water continues to flow, and now you'll need both a plumber and additional repairs. The tenant looks worried as water damage spreads to the hallway.

The emergency plumber arrives within 30 minutes and quickly shuts off the water. While this was the safe choice, the delay allowed more water damage to occur, and the emergency call-out fee is substantial.

choices.text: Document the damage for insurance

nodes.text: You call for professional help while the water continues to flow. The plumber arrives quickly, but the extended flooding has caused significant damage to the unit and hallway flooring.

You carefully document all the water damage with photos and notes. The tenant appreciates your thoroughness: 'At least I know this will be handled properly.' The insurance claim should cover most of the repair costs.
